abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings convey a satisfactory project
            outcome, highly likely sustainability, though modest
            institutional development impacts. Following are some
            factors that conditioned program implementation, and thus
            become important lessons for future operations. There is an
            urgent need for the Bank to monitor the economic and
            financial situation of Uruguay more closely. This was
            evident given both the 2000 Country Assistance Strategy
            (CAS), as well as the Bank work in the financial sector
            early in 2002, failed to perceive the risks threatening the
            Uruguayan economy, as a result of the financial crisis in
            Argentina, which hindered the initial preparation of the
            operation. Had the program been backed by stronger
            foundation within the CAS, and by the Bank's economic
            and sector work, there would have been greater information,
            and closeness with government officials, which no doubt
            would have led to an improved operation. Notwithstanding,
            actions implemented by the Bank team helped overcome some
            serious problems, such as the lack of a unified social
            policy authority in the country to act as a counterpart,
            forcing a program design and supervision at preparation with
            no Government support. As it happened, the Ministry of
            Economy was just a contact facilitator, with no power to
            develop the preparation of the program, particularly
            regarding social protection. Furthermore, there is need to
            maintain a dialogue with the Government on relevant
            structural reforms/policy actions with a long-term
            sustainable impact on the social sectors. A more consistent
            social development strategy would have helped design a more
            ambitious reform agenda. In retrospect, the project was
            effective given the seemingly medium and long term
            sustainable impact, in areas such as transparency,
            coherency, safety net, social information, and, monitoring
            and evaluation of the programs.
